net.tmachine.gpg4.gameserver
Class HTTPResponse

java.lang.Object
  net.tmachine.gpg4.gameserver.HTTPResponse
public class HTTPResponse
extends java.lang.Object

This is a simple, straightforward implementation of methods and data to represent and create HTTP responses.

It is sufficient as an example, although not recommended for production code. In most cases, you will create a new protocol class of your own anyway.

Notes:

  • This class uses the ISO-8859-1 Charset explicitly. Java on different platforms doesn't always default to this Charset, even when the system is apparently set to the correct Locale. It is necessary to ALWAYS explicitly set the Charset, otherwise you may not have any idea what language your server is attempting to speak to clients...

See Also:
HTTPRequest

Constructor Detail

HTTPResponse

public HTTPResponse(java.nio.channels.SelectableChannel sc)
WARNING: This constructor only allocates 1000-characters for the headers. In practice, this is usually sufficient for all responses, but some uses of an HTTP server (e.g. if you have very many cookies, or long cookies) will require longer headers - or possibly even variable-size header-buffer allocations (for efficiency)

getCharset

setRedirect

public void setRedirect(java.lang.String newURL)
Uses the HTTP return-codes to cause the clients browser to automatically re-direct to the new URL

Parameters:
newURL - this is a String because the java URL class is too much hassle just to manage something as simple as a URL (e.g. you have to catch pointless Exception's). This String should be EXACTLY the address you want to redirect to (according to the "Location" header in HTTP) - i.e. usually this means including "http://" at the start of your String, but not necessarily.

setNotAllowed

public void setNotAllowed(java.util.Vector allowableMethods)
Used to indicate that an HTTP method (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, etc) was attempted on a resource (web-page etc) that does not allow that method (e.g. staticpages cannot be POST'd to).

According to the HTTP spec, browsers should automatically retry a different request where possible, but most seem to ignore this.

killCookie

public void killCookie(java.lang.String name)
Causes an extra header-line to be added that explicitly kills a cookie - this is useful for logging out people if your login uses cookies to maintain state

setByteBuffersFrom

public void setByteBuffersFrom(java.util.Vector v,
                               HTTPRequest request)
This is the most important method of all: When you have a Vector of BB's containing the data you wish to return as teh body of the response, you call this method, and it generates all the HTTP headers, and attaches a COPY of the list of BB's (although it only copies references to the BB's, not the BB's themselves).

Parameters:
v - Vector of ByteBuffer's containing data to send
request - the original HTTPRequest that this is replying to (necessary in order to set some headers) or null if none is available (e.g. if replying to a malformed HTTPRequest)

getHeaderBuffer

protected java.nio.ByteBuffer getHeaderBuffer(HTTPRequest request)
Assuming the byteBuffers variable has already been set with the body of the response, this generates the headers.

Sets the HTTP status code. Note that uf you call this more than once, it is ignored on all successive calls.
